comment.author: 22235551@N05
comment._content:
amazing to see these people who could be tied into the Ainu of Japan, at least that's what's theorized.   Going back this far into photography shows sometimes cultures still untainted by modernization.

The collar is clearly there is just a slight tone closer to the gray background if you do all sizes you can see it quite clearly.

comment.author: 10749411@N03
comment._content: As mentioned before, I believe the "Inuit" are related to the Egyptian devotees of the Sky Goddess "Nut" who is often depicted as "all the stars in the night sky". Racially, this group of Inuit differs from other photographs of other Inuit, in that this group has distinct Caucasian features, sharp nose, round eyes, for example as opposed to flatter wider nose and Asian features of others. www.flickr.com/photos/nationalmaritimemuseum/2842856517/i... I suggest that there were Pictish peoples from the Scotland and Ireland areas that integrated into these tribes, and made their way all the way down to Virginia. The Picts of Scotland/Ireland became the Pequots, Massapequa, Chesapeake, Chappequa, Chippewa of the Americas, etc. The Nut Egyptian figure is appropriate for the area of the North Atlantic where the sky dropped down to the earth in misty rain, fog, blizzards, white outs, etc. making living very difficult, if not dangerous. In addition, I am also suggesting that the Egyptian God "Shu" and Goddess "Nut", preceded the role of the Greek Titan Atlas, holding up the celestial heavens, and the rock piles found all across Northern Canada probably testify to this veneration. See also... www.flickr.com/photos/10749411@N03/5172065297/ These are extremely important, informative photographs, that tell a very deep story.

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content: Thanks to research by a curator it has been found that the Inglefield Album held by the Royal Archives records that the people in the photograph are (l-r) Mother, Daughter, Fiance, and Sister-in-Law.

comment.author: 10749411@N03
comment._content:
First of all, thank you for the response.  I am told that Asian looking people washed up in fishing boats along the Irish and Scottish shores, over the last hundreds of years.  The reverse I believe is also true, where Viking and Celtic and Irish and Scottish fishermen were blown off course and integrated into the Inuit (Nut) cultures.  

Am I wrong in thinking that this beautiful group looks somewhat Irish/Scottish?

Thanks again for the research and the response.

comment.author: 82486786@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/10749411@N03] it is true that the vikings came to inuit cultures, but the once coming to Greenland were Norwegian/Danish. Also their clothing is quite similar to what we wear in Westgreenland, (except for formal occations we have added on a pearl collar) so I would believe these people were a mix between danes and greenlanders. :) The link below is for the national "costume" :) www.google.com/search?hl=da&rls=com.microsoft:da:IE-A...

comment.author: 10749411@N03
comment._content: Thank you for your response.  These old  photos are enormously important in proving, in a small way, the diffusion of cultures to and from both sides of the Atlantic, and why should we be surprised.

comment.author: 10749411@N03
comment._content: Joe... continuiing the discussion on a different tack... Is there any significance to the hair style that is shown? Let me give another example, how Southwest indigenous women would wear what is called a "Rams Horm" spiral in their hair, which I have associated with veneration to Amun, "Horns of Amun", possibly in the epoch of the "Ram" constellation, I am not sure. This hair style shown looks remarkably similar to the head crown of Hades, as shown in my Flickr article of a year ago... www.flickr.com/photos/10749411@N03/5305209273/in/set-7215... It is one of those maddening, circumstantial, kinda-sorta close, but no definitive match things... The hair styles were meaningful to the ancient women, and I think the photo you show plausibly is in that realm of possibility, as in "Hades venderation" what do you think?
